oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten on envelope: ''#453 JCRS Buildings, #453 JCRS Physical Plant''. On back of photograph: ''#453 JCRS Possibly I. Rude Building Dentist Office (?) - 1920s''.

Interior of an unidentified room, possibly in the I. Rude Medical Building, on the campus of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Beck Archives Photograph Collection, Health Care and Philanthropy

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten on envelope: ''#457 JCRS Personalities''. On back of photograph: ''#457 JCRS Nathaniel Goldstein Attorney General State of New York 1951''.

Nathaniel Goldstein, Attorney General for the State of New York from 1943 to 1954. Goldstein was a personality and supporter of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches, black and white
